column1: An open pleural biopsy is a procedure to remove and examine the tissue that lines the inside of the chest.
An open pleural biopsy is done in the hospital using general anesthesia, which means you are asleep and pain-free.
Most surgeons inject a long-acting local anesthetic at the surgical cut site so that you will have very little pain afterwards.
Abnormal findings may be due to: - Abnormal tissue growth (neoplasms) - Disease due to a virus, fungus, or parasite - Mesothelioma - Tuberculosis
